docs.lead_paragraph: The president’s allies and adversaries agree on one thing: that an unraveling of subsidies in the Affordable Care Act would be devastating.

headline.main: A Ruling Against Obama Would Damage, Not Negate, a Health Care Legacy
headline.print_headline: A Ruling Against Obama Would Damage, Not Erase, a Health Care Legacy

docs.abstract: Health care experts say while Supreme Court ruling against federal subsidies contained within Pres Obama's health care reform law would damage legacy he sought to leave, many positive aspects of law would remain in effect; yet such a ruling would mean years of uncertainty surrounding law, and Republicans are excited by possibility that court could hamper law in way they have failed to do legislatively.
docs.snippet: The president’s allies and adversaries agree on one thing: that an unraveling of subsidies in the Affordable Care Act would be devastating.

docs.lead_paragraph: Democrats were prepared to quickly come up with a legislative solution should the U.S. Supreme Court rule in the next few days to invalidate a central part of President Barack Obama's signature healthcare law, party leaders in the Senate said on Tuesday.

docs.lead_paragraph: Significant declines in the proportion of uninsured Americans are documented as the Supreme Court nears a ruling on Affordable Care Act subsidies.

headline.main: Fewer Poor Uninsured After Health Law, Study Finds
headline.print_headline: Data Confirms Drop in Share of Poor Who Are Uninsured

docs.abstract: National Health Interview Survey reports substantial decline in number of poor Americans without health insurance since Affordable Care Act took effect.

docs.lead_paragraph: All the deal-making in the health care industry is largely the result of the Affordable Care Act, which in effect caps hospitals’ and insurers’ profits.

headline.main: Health Care Law Spurs Merger Talks for Insurers
headline.print_headline: Health Care Law Spurs Merger Talks for Insurers

docs.abstract: Andrew Ross Sorkin DealBook column underscores fact that merger talks among nation's top five health insurers is result of Affordable Care Act and the way it limits how much profit hospitals and insurers can make; notes while consolidation will save insurers money, it is not clear whether these savings will be passed on to consumers.
docs.snippet: All the deal-making in the health care industry is largely the result of the Affordable Care Act, which in effect caps hospitals’ and insurers’ profits.

docs.lead_paragraph: Cigna has rejected Anthem, while Williams has spurned Energy Transfer. In a hot merger market like this, love won’t be unrequited forever.

headline.main: A Taylor Swift Moment for Mergers and Acquisitions
